title: Friday, 30th October, 2015

11:02 am

But should explain the context first

PM

This came out of Valeant earlier

PM

LAVAL, Quebec, Oct. 30, 2015 PRNewswire -- Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, Inc. (NYSE: VRX) (TSX: VRX) announced today that it is severing all ties with Philidor Rx Services, LLC, and that Philidor has informed Valeant that it will shut down operations as soon as possible, consistent with applicable laws.

"The newest allegations about activities at Philidor raise additional questions about the company's business practices," said J. Michael Pearson, Valeant's chairman and chief executive officer. "We have lost confidence in Philidor's ability to continue to operate in a manner that is acceptable to Valeant and the patients and doctors we serve."

"We understand that patients, doctors and business partners have been disturbed by the reports of improper behavior at Philidor, just as we have been," Pearson said. "We know the allegations have also led them to question Valeant and our integrity, and for that I take complete responsibility. Operating honestly and ethically is our first priority, and you have my absolute commitment that we will make it right."

11:03 am
PM

Valeant intends to develop a plan to ensure patients' access to drugs is minimally disrupted. Valeant has informed Philidor that to the extent that managed care plans will no longer reimburse prescriptions in process, Valeant will fill them at the company's expense.

"We are committed to doing everything we can to provide important medicines to the patients and doctors who depend on them, and will continue to explore relationships with the full range of pharmacies to ensure patients have access to the drugs they need," Pearson said.

(Which brings us back to the philosophical question of whether or not you can sever ties with something if you claim not to own it but have a contract where you can take control of it for free. But that's for another time.)

11:14 am
BE

CVS and ESRX have both terminated Philidor from their pharmacy
networks. We est Philidor contributed 35% of YTD U.S. organic
growth, but downside risk may be mitigated through use of other
pharmacies. Remain EW VRX given risk of ongoing scrutiny, but we
believe fraud concerns may be overblown

BE

CVS and ESRX have reportedly dropped Philidor from their pharmacy
networks. Reports cite that CVS has taken action due to "noncompliance" with
its provider agreement, following weeks of monitoring and reviewing recent
audits of Philidor's practices. ESRX is reportedly reviewing all "captive
pharmacy arrangements" in which a manufacturer dominates a given
pharmacy's business. The risk to Valeant is that prescriptions for CVS and
ESRX beneficiaries may face greater reimbursement hurdles at non-Philidor
pharmacies, which could lead to lower fulfillment rates.

BE

Noncompliance may have involved certain claims processing; was
Philidor's mail order also an Achilles' heel? CVS has stated that Philidor
did not follow the terms of its provider agreement, but we do not know the
specific area(s) of non-compliance. The media has reported that Philidor may
have circumvented formulary management by filing some claims under one
provider number and then switching claims to another provider number after
the first claims were rejected. Another possibility is that a plan could claim
non-compliance with its exclusive mail order contract(s) for traditional drugs–
e.g. that Philidor violated exclusive mail order arrangements. We await future
newsflow to gain more clarity and to see if litigation ensues after plans drop
Philidor.

11:15 am
BE

Philidor and related specialty pharmacies accounted for only 7.2% of
global revenue; we estimate Philidor contributed over a third of
reported 27% US organic growth. 7.2% of VRX YTD global revenues
represents ~$555M (~$740M annualized). In our Base Case scenario, we
assume Philidor achieved 50% of those revenues at this point last year
($278M). The incremental $278M of Philidor revenues YTD implies that
Philidor accounted for 35% of U.S. organic growth...and contributed 10
percentage points of Valeant's 27% US YOY organic growth. See Exhibit 1 for
details, including our High, Base, and Low scenarios.

BE

The volume impact from plans blocking Philidor can be mitigated if
prescriptions are filled via other pharmacies. Valeant may seek to partner
with other third-party specialty pharmacies which may drive volume less
effectively but could still help fulfill prescription demand.

BE

Tthe US's commercialisation of its drug supply chain rivals prohibition as its most dumb-headed, counterproductive and ultimately destructive decision.

should therefore havelimited impact on Glencore's investment case.The next

The production cuts Glencoreannounced for copper and zinc will mostly start

Mopani for 3Q.
In thermal coal thecuts in production in Australia and exit from Optimum coal
should impactvolumes in 3Q.Weestimate 18.1 million metric tons of export
thermal coal volumes in 3Q versus 23.6 million metric tons in 3Q 2014.

PM

BG Group reported its 3Q15 results this morning with a 40% beat at the bottom line, reporting adj net income of $280m vs consensus at $200m (RBCe $251m), mainly driven by a lower effective tax rate. At the operating income line, BG was broadly in line with consensus. With volumes coming in ahead of both our and consensus guidance, the company has also raised full year production guidance to 680-700kboed (previously upper half of 650-690kboed). The company has also lowered its capex guidance to $6.5bn, the bottom end of the range given at the start of the year.

11:01 am
PM

Welcome

BE

IAG has reported its third quarter results this morning and our first take is that
they are in-line. Expectations of a strong Q3 have been met; IAG has reported
Q3 EBIT of E1250m (E1 205m ex-Aer Lingus); the E1205m is in-line with DBE
E1 204m and consensus E1 190m. In Q3 (pre-AERL, consFX) passenger unit
revenues were down 3.3% (Q2 down 6.6%) against ex-fuel unit costs down
3.5% (Q2 down 6.9%). As is normal at this juncture, IAG has firmed up FY15
EBIT guidance (ex-AERL) to E2250m to E2300m (previously E2200m+). In our
view this is broadly in-line with sell-side expectations (DBE E2344m/consensus
E2190m), albeit peer results suggest investors may be ahead of this. Aer
Lingus was acquired on 18th August 2015 and has contributed E45m of
operating profit to date but in Q4-14 lost E31m and so it is reasonable to
assume its impact on group FY15 EBIT will be negligible.

BE

In its statement IAG has not given much indication of its Q4/Q1 outlook and so
its presentation and conference call will be closely followed at 0900 UKT. Our
first glance at the presentation suggests FY15 fuel bill guidance is unchanged
at E6.0bn but this now includes AERL as well so there is a small implicit cut.
Q4 capacity growth at the group level has been cut from 4.6% to 4.1% with
marginal cuts at BA and VY against a slight increase at IB. The Q3 ASK/RASK
mix suggests a much improved QoQ pan-network consFX RASK performance
with Domestic and Europe particularly strong. The North Atlantic also appears
to still be performing very well.
Overall, we believe IAG has met the base of expectations ahead of its annual
capital markets day on the 6th of November.

11:34 am
BE

Other points
In our view management is unlikely to shed too much light on major strategic
issues and will instead address these fully at the capital markets day next
week. We believe the focal points will be (i) what IAG plans to do with its
excess cash generation, (ii) a strategic update on Aer Lingus and (iii)
capacity/capex. On the 2015 dividend, we note the approved interim of E0.10
yesterday which suggests a 50:50 interim:final split going forward if we
assume a FY15 25% payout ratio.

BE

Performance into results, valuation
IAG shares have been broadly flat over the last month versus (post yesterday’s
movements) LHA +11%, AFKLM -4%, EZJ -3% and RYA flat. It trades on below
8x 2016 PE and 3.7x 2016 EV/EBITDAR. We believe IAG is one of the best
opportunities in the sector.

International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 574.25, down 23.25 (-3.89%), High: 582.00, Low: 567.00, Volume: 8.03m

11:44 am
PM

PAH has delivered weaker-than-expected sales growth for 1H16 as Health & Hygiene continued to face seasonal challenges. However, core strategic drivers including Advanced Nutrition, Services, Omnichannel and VIP Club are performing well. Management expects consensus EBITDA to decrease by c.3% to £127m and continues to flag FY16 profitability will be H2 weighted, as the strong Health & Hygiene comparatives ease. Given the shares trade at c.23x P/E, it is likely the shares will react negatively to this morning’s announcement. While some investors may look to lock in profits today, we continue to believe the premium rating is merited given PAH’s ‘category killer’ status and its exposure to structurally attractive markets. We remain on our BUY recommendation.

BE

Is "category killer" an appropriate phrase to use here?

PM

A category killer is a product, service, brand, or company that has such a distinct sustainable competitive advantage that competing firms find it almost impossible to operate profitably in that industry (or in the same local area).

11:45 am
BE

Dead cat bounce, also, to be avoided.

Pets at Home

11:47 am
BE

- The key figure in this statement is the LFL sales growth, which was +1.8% in
FY1H implying only a marginal improvement from +1.7% in FY1Q to +1.9% in
FY2Q (vs. MSe +2.7%). Overall, this is another lackluster performance after the
FY1Q, which was also adversely affected by the weather-led poor flea season
in Health & Hygiene. While management highlighted that the poor flea season
negatively impacted the group LFL by 0.9% in FY1Q, it did not provide this
number for FY2Q but underlined a significant impact this quarter as well.

BE

- The FY15/16e outlook has also changed from "Our full year outlook remains
in-line with market expectations.“ in the FY1Q statement to "Our full year profit
outlook is broadly in line with market expectations". Consensus is currently
looking for FY15/16e LFL of 2.9%, Pre Tax Profits of £98m and EPS of 15.5p.
Given the weaker-than-expected LFLs and the unchanged cost outlook, we
expect consensus to come down by 2-3% today.

BE

- Based on last night's closing price and existing consensus forecasts, Pets at
Home is trading on 18.1x Cal 2016 earnings, 11.8x EBITDA, with a 2.2%
dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 15.5x,
8.9x and 3.2%, respectively.

11:49 am

PM

tNAV per share of 384p (+4p QoQ) is better than our 380p and consensus of 375p. The CET1 capital ratio rises 0.4% QoQ to 12.7% and it is confirmed that RBS is moving ahead with a final disposal of Citizens; the pro forma CET1 ratio is 16.2%. Attributable Profit is £1.0bn vs a consensus expectation of a £0.2bn loss! We do not deny that RBS still faces a long walk back to RotE greater than 10%, but we believe that a large share buyback in 2017e will prove transformational. Trading on just 0.8x, the time for waiting is over! BUY.

11:52 am
BE

2017 share buyback? Hm.

BE

Not sure I can get my head around the share count going from public to private then getting retired.

BE

Here's Cazenove.

11:53 am
BE

RBS Q3 results were mixed with weak performance on P&L (PBT 15% below
cons impacted by IFRS volatility). CET1 (+40bps q/q) and TNAV (+9p) were
better relative to company consensus but in line with our expectations. Within
divisions, the weak top line in UK PBB (-1% q/q) and Commercial (-7% q/q)
is likely to drive consensus EPS downgrades, in our view, and uncertainty
around the eventual litigation costs is likely to remain a headwind for the
shares. With the shares trading at 0.9x trough P/TNAV, we remain Neutral.

BE

 Q3 results summary: Clean PBT in Q3 was £842m, down 45% q/q on a
like-for-like basis and was 15% below cons and 23% vs JPMe. However, it
includes IFRS volatility of -£126m and, excluding that, the PBT would have
been 2% below cons and 12% below JPMe. Relative to expectations: 1)
Revenues of £3.0bn were 5% below cons. Ex IFRS volatility, revenues were
1% below cons. 2) Costs of £2.3bn are 5% above cons, and 3) Provision
release of £79m compares with £42m provisions for cons.
 Capital and TNAV: CET1 ratio increased 40bps q/q to 12.7% (16.2% pro
forma for disposals) & was in line with JPMe but 30bps above cons.
TNAV/s was +4p q/q to 384p, in line with JPMe but 9p above cons.
 Balance sheet: Net loans declined 1% in the quarter mainly due to CIB
as other divisions showed strong growth trends with mortgages being the
key area of focus. UK PBB loans grew 3% in the quarter, Ulster loans
were +1% in the quarter. Commercial loans were +1.5%.
 Divisional results summary: UK PBB, Commercial, Private Banking and
CIB profits declined q/q but Ulster PBT improved q/q. Relative to
expectations (JPMe): UK PBB and Commercial profits were below and
Ulster and CIB were above expectations, although CIB was still a loss. UK
PBB: Clean PBT of £663m was -5% q/q and 6% below JPMe due to lower
revenues and higher costs. UK PBB revenues were down 1% q/q and 5% y/y
due to margin pressure. Ulster: Clean PBT of £122m was +34% q/q due to
better revenues and ongoing provision releases, partly offset by higher costs.
Commercial: Clean PBT of £413m was -13% q/q and 17% below JPMe due
to lower revenues and higher costs. Commercial revenues were down 7%
q/q but up 2% y/y. CIB: Clean PBT loss of £268m was higher than Q2 loss
due to lower revenues, only partly offset by lower costs. CIB total revenues
were -16% q/q but CIB go-forward revenues were only -1% q/q

BE

And RBC

11:54 am
BE

Our view: the 5% miss on income (9% miss RBCe) combined with a negative outlook in respect of NIM and fees is of most concern to us. We think the market is over optimistic on the go
forward bank earnings potential and these results will further highlight this. On the positive side CET1 progression, proforma for CFG disposal (to complete by year end) is 16.2% up from
15.3% in Q2. TBVPS growth to 384p puts the shares on 0.83x.
15% miss on adjusted PBT. Adj. operating profit of £842m compares to £988m consensus, £1,145m RBCe so miss of 15% and 26% respectively. The miss is driven by income, 5% miss for
consensus and 9% RBCe. Underlying costs were 5% 3% higher (worse) than consensus RBCe. Beat on impairments; £79m writebacks, down from £141m in Q2
£42m for consensus and writebacks of £3m RBCe. This is the 6th quarter of writebacks.
£1.1bn gain on CFG disposal not in consensus so beat at net profit. Per the 29 July RNS following the disposal of CFG, RBS has booked a gain of £1,147m in discontinued operations of which
£962m is a reclassification from FX reserves so the TNAV impact is the net amount of £185m. This compares to £1.1bn and £0.9bn guidance and so in line with our forecasts. Net attributable
profit of £952m compares to £1,392m RBCe, 32% miss, and a loss of £179m for consensus.
Income miss. Total income is 5% below consensus and 9% below RBCe. We model the bank on go-forward and exit bank basis and the detail for income on this structure does not suggest
any one division has significantly contributed to the miss. NIM for the group is down 4bps to 2.09% which a reduction in all except CIB. UK PBB NIM is down 4bps to 3.54% and Commercial
down 5bps to 2.81%.NII is down 1% Q/Q (ex CFG) due to lower CIB balances. Non-interest income is down 36% Q/Q and 32% Y/Y driven by lower trading income and fees.
Costs higher but guidance on savings improved. Costs ex restructuring and litigation are 5% higher than consensus and 3% higher than RBCe. Management has already exceeded its 2015 cost
save target of £800m (£700m achieved in H1) and has increased the target to greater than £900m. Restructuring charges were £847m vs £874m consensus and £300m RBCe. Litigation/conduct
were £129m vs £451m consensus and £100m RBCe. There was no PPI top-up (22 months coverage) and £120m of the £129m went to general litigation top-ups. Balance sheet provisions are
stable at £4.5bn.
Balance sheet progress good. TNAV per share is 384p up from 380p at end Q2. This is in line with our 383p forecast but ahead of 375p consensus. CET1 ratio is up 40bps to
consensus but below RBCe 13.2% (we had lower RWA and great DTA unwind). Proforma for CGF disposal, final tranche announced today, CET1 is 16.2% versus 15.3% at end Q2.
Outlook: Flagging NIM compression and fee pressure. The outlook statement reads more negatively highlighting continued pressure on asset yields due to competition and limited
opportunities for liabilities to reprice lower, hence NIM compression is set to continue. The statement also flags subdued fee income given muted volumes and interchange fee changes.
There is nothing new in respect of restructuring / litigation guidance.

BE

You get the idea.

We are reducing our Cineworld recommendation to SELL from Buy with a new, lowered share price target of 535p (from 620p), implying c10% downside. It’s time to take profits. Cineworld’s share price is up 75% over the last 12 months driven in large part by this year’s fantastic film slate that climaxes this quarter with three blockbusters: Bond Spectre, Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2 and Star Wars: the Force Awakens yet Cineworld traditionally under-indexes versus Odeon and Vue on blockbusters and our research suggests this quarter will be no exception. This quarter is as good as it gets for the cinema industry. Next year's film slate is less strong and it could be a 'crowded trade' when the market wakes up to a duller outlook not helped by the distractions of the Olympics and the UEFA European Football Championships next summer.

11:57 am
PM

Missed opportunity - the detail

PM

Our analysis round the three autumn blockbusters shows that Odeon is more aggressive on the allocation of screens and Vue is more aggressive on price. Cineworld does not believe in revenue yield optimization. Until it does, we believe it will continue to underperform during industry peaks. We are coming to the view that Cineworld is better at building cinemas in unsophisticated East Europe where competition is weak than optimizing performance from its sophisticated UK portfolio where competition is intense.

We estimate Cineworld could be missing out on as much as £2.2m of additional EBITDA per blockbuster in the UK. Assuming a blockbuster/quarter that puts Cineworld’s missed UK opportunity at £8.8m. For 4Q15, with three potential blockbusters, the scale of the missed opportunity may be as much as £6.6m. To put this in context, the UK accounts for c65% of Cineworld EBIT and we are forecasting an H2 EBIT contribution of £44.7m for the UK and £65.4m for group EBIT. It’s a very material lost opportunity for Cineworld. Potential year-end upgrades should not be mistaken for an excellent performance: a rising tide lifts all ships.

PM

Our new 535p target price valuation is equivalent to 18.8x PER, 10.0x EV/EBITDA, an 8.0% FCF yield and 3.0% dividend yield for FY15E. The current share price of 594p values the stock on a P/E of 20.9x for FY15E, 18.9x FY16E, an EV/EBITDA of 10.9x falling to 10.0x, a FCF yield of 7.2% rising to 7.9% and dividend yield of 2.7% rising to 2.9% over the same period. It now looks an expensive stock following its re-rating over the last 12 months.
